document.masterDocTitle: ' The curse of Horaeomorphus ': taxonomy of misplaced Australian Cyrtoscydmini (Coleoptera: Staphylinidae: Scydmaeninae)

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: ' The curse of Horaeomorphus ': taxonomy of misplaced Australian Cyrtoscydmini (Coleoptera: Staphylinidae: Scydmaeninae)

subSubSection.paragraph:
Type species:
Scydmaenus simplicicornis
Lea, 1910
: 185
(here designated).
Description. Body ( Figs. 46, 48 ) 2.20–2.58 in length, strongly convex, elongate but moderately slender, with long appendages, pigmentation from reddish-brown to nearly black, cuticle setose.
Hind wings well-developed, about twice as long as elytra.

Etymology.
Leascydmus
is a name dedicated to Arthur Mills Lea, an Australian entomologist who described many Scydmaeninae and in the description of
Scydmaenus simplicicornis
wrote: "the species may eventually be regarded as belonging to a new genus", which proved correct. Gender masculine.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURES 37–41. Morphology of
Leascydmus armstrongi
sp. n.
Head in dorsal (37) and ventral (38) views, labrum in dorsal view (39), right mandible in dorsal view (40), and left maxilla in ventral view (41). Abbreviations: bst, basistipes; cd, cardo; cl, clypeus; fo, foramen occipitale; fr, frons; gal, galea; gp, gular plate; gs, gular suture; hr, hypomeral ridge; lac, lacinia; lbr, labrum; lg, ligula; md, mandible; mn, mentum; mst, mediostipes; mxp, maxillary palpus; mxp1–4, maxillary palpomere 1–4; occ, occipital constriction; ocp, occiput; pmn, prementum; ppf, palpifer; pst, prostheca; ptp, posterior tentorial pit; smn, submentum; tm, temple; vt, vertex.

FIGURES 42–45. Morphology of
Leascydmus armstrongi
sp. n.
Base of pronotum and elytra in dorsal view (42), prothorax in ventral view (43), meso- and metanotum in dorsal view (44), pterothorax in ventral view (45). Abbreviations: aest3, metanepisternum; alc, alacrista; amvp, anterior metaventral process; ar, anterior ridge; bef, basal elytral fovea; bst, basisternal part of prosternum; cx3, metacoxa; dlf, dorsolateral fovea; elb, elytral base; hd, humeral denticle; hy, hypomeron; hyr, hypomeral ridge; lmfa, lateral metafurcal arm; mcp, mesocoxal projection; mma, median membranous area; mscc, mesocoxal cavity; mscs, mesocoxal socket; msf, mesofurca; msvp, mesoventral process; mtvp, metaventral intercoxal process; nss, pronotosternal suture; pcc, procoxal cavity; pcr, procoxal rest; pcs, procoxal socket; pff, profurcal fovea; pre, prepectus; psn3, metapostnotum; sc2, mesoscutellum; sc3, metascutum; sss, mesoscutoscutellar suture; tr3, metatrochanter; v3, metaventrite; vlf, ventrolateral fovea; wb, wing base.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Remarks.
Leascydmus
is a remarkable genus because of its superficial similarity to
Scydmaenus
Latreille, 1802
. The general shape of the pronotum and elytra, the broad metaventral intercoxal process and relatively long metatrochanters resemble some subgenera of
Scydmaenus
, from which
Leascydmus
differs in the diagnostic characters of Cyrtoscydmini (e.g., the subconical maxillary palpomere IV; discussed in
Jałoszyński 2012 c
). Among Australian Cyrtoscydmini open procoxal sockets can be found only in
Palaeoscydmaenus Franz
, but this genus has a clearly different habitus, with subtriangular head, the 'neck region' nearly as broad as vertex and much less distinctly demarcated from the anterior part of the head capsule, and the pronotum elongate and broadest in the anterior part. Besides,
Palaeoscydmaenus
belongs to a group of genera characterized by the submentum demarcated laterally by complete lateral sutures, which are absent in
Leascydmus
.
Leascydmus
differs from all Australian genera without lateral sutures of submentum in rudimentary hypostomal ridges (shared only by
Microscydmus
and Penicillidmus , but these genera include beetles not reaching 1 mm in length, with 3 -segmented antennal club, and antebasal pits on pronotum), tempora, genae and postgenae covered only with setae, without bristles, open procoxal sockets and broadly separated metacoxae (character shared with at least some subgenera of
Euconnus
, including
Euconnus
s. str. , but the latter genus has pits and sometimes transverse grooves on the base of pronotum and long, continuous and strongly expanding ventrally, keel-shaped mesoventral intercoxal process). The short head with arcuate posterior margin of convex vertex, short pronotum without pits or grooves, humeral denticles and strongly elongate antennae with the antennomere XI as long as IX–X together are sufficient to identify
Leascydmus
.
